body: It should work. Did you try the latest from MyGet?
Oh, sorry. No, NuGet. I can try MyGet when I get back to work tomorrow, if it matters.

Back to work now. With version 4.2.0-ci-1038, I get the same behavior.

I'm trying to build a MWE that reproduces the problem, but I'm not getting the error there, so it's likely this is something in my actual mappings that's not working, and not an issue with AutoMapper. I'll keep trying and get back with the results, whether this is a bug or PEBKAC.
Kind of subtle and you can easily workaround it. But I'll take a look.
What's a good workaround? Is there one that still lets me have the optional argument first (since that really makes much more sense in my actual application)?
I haven't found a way to use ConstructUsing that doesn't require me to explicitly specify all the parameters. If I have to do that, I might as well not use AutoMapper...

issue.title: Faling test for #1023
issue.body:
This adds a failing test for #1023. If a property

```
public int Bar { get; set; }
```

is added to the `SourceFoo` type, and the setup is updated accordingly,
the test passes, but I would like it to work without that property.

body: Hopefully you use it for other things too :)

I do, which is why I want this to work too :)

The reason I'm trying to get this to work is that we want the types that I'm mapping to to be immutable, so we give them get-only properties which are initialized from the constructor. This specific type, and a few others like it, have an optional Id property, which should either be provided in a constructor argument, or be `null` (and stay `null`). All other properties are mandatory.

Since we do all other transformations of this kind in AutoMapper, it would be a shame if we couldn't do that here either - if for no other reason, then because of consistency across the code base. (And we're probably moving towards more such immutable types, so the scenarios where AutoMapper can be used will then become less and less if this isn't implemented...).

Apparently even a constructor with an optional parameter doesn't work so I think we have something here.

```
public Qux(string bar, int baz=42)
```

Yeah; I guess the error message is to be interpreted very literally. With some emphasis:

>  needs to have a constructor with 0 args or **only** optional args

Without having inspected the internals, I guess this implies that AutoMapper _always_ uses an argument-less constructor, and then fills in the blanks (with reflection if it has to). I think it would be very valuable to support also true mapping to constructor arguments, but I realize it might be more work than I thought this would be when I filed the issue.
No, it does the mapping, but not in this case.
So would optional parameters solve your case? Because this seems easy to do.

Sure, if it's OK that not all parameters are optional :) In other words, requiring `public Qux(string foo, int bar = 17)` rather than two different constructors is perfectly fine; requiring `public Qux(string foo = null, int bar = 17)` doesn't help.
This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
